Award.AwardTitle: 2018 ENVR Workshop "Statistics for the Environment: Research, Practice and Policy"
Award.AbstractNarration:
The workshop, Statistics for the Environment: Research, Practice and Policy, will serve as the biennial workshop of the section on Statistics and the Environment (ENVR) of the American Statistical Association and will be held in Asheville, North Carolina, October 11-13, 2018. The workshop is designed to achieve three major goals: (i) provide a venue for environmental statisticians and practitioners to share ideas, facilitate collaboration and discuss ways to increase the impact and use of statistics in environmental practice and policy; (ii) provide an opportunity for environmental statisticians and environmental scientists to discuss and present novel statistical methods and new research findings in environmental and ecological disciplines; and (iii) provide training in new statistical methods developed to address some of the statistical and computational challenges typically posed by environmental and ecological data.

The workshop will span two and a half days. During the first day, two short courses on high performance computing and hierarchical modeling, respectively, will take place. The second and third day will be devoted to scientific sessions with invited research talks on statistical methods for environmental and ecological data as well as applications. A contributed poster session will be held at the end of the second day. Topics discussed in the invited sessions include: statistical methods to handle massive, spatially correlated datasets and strategies for efficient computing; statistical models for spatial extremes; statistical methods for causal inference in an environmental context and understanding the (causal) effects of environmental exposures on human health and the environment, to name a few. The last day of the workshop will feature an invited panel discussion that will highlight cogent needs in environmental practice and policy and will examine possible avenues for impactful environmental statistics research. More information on the workshop is available at: http://community.amstat.org/envr/events/envr2018workshop

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 ENVR Workshop "Statistics for the Environment: Research, Practice and Policy" was held in Asheville, North Carolina in October 2018. The workshop was attended by 66 domestic and international participants and featured 15 invited talks by both junior and more established statisticians working on scientific problems rooted in environmental sciences and environmental health (e.g. forestry, ecology, atmospheric sciences, etc.). The workshop also featured a poster session, and a panel discussion on cogent needs in environmental practice and policy.

 The workshop accomplished three main goals. The first was to initiate discussions among environmental statisticians and practitioners on ways statistics can play a more impactful role in environmental practice and policy. The second was to facilitate the sharing of new research findings and state of the art methods in spatial and environmental statistics. The third was to provide training opportunities on computational methods to tackle some of the emerging computational challenges faced by environmental statisticians in the analysis of environmental data.

The first day of the workshop featured two short courses: one, on efficient computational methods for large-dimensional spatial data taught by Dorit Hammerling of Colorado School of Mines jointly with Andrew Finley of Michigan State University, and the other one on hierarchical modeling for spatial data, taught by  Chris Paciorek of University of California, Berkeley. The following two days featured research talks on statistical methods and analysis of environmental data, including, among others, methods to detect human impact on climate change, models to assess the causal effect on health of power plants regulations, statistical models to forecast plant populations, and climate monitoring. Talks were given by a mix of junior researchers - graduate student, postdocs and Assistant Professors - as well as more senior statistical researchers. Additionally, presenters represented both statisticians in academic institutions as well as environmental statisticians working in research labs and government agencies. A poster session on the evening of the second day of the workshop and a panel discussion on the role of environmental statistics in environmental policy concluded the workshop on October 13, 2018.

Travel funds from NSF through this award supported students' travel, registration, and part of rental venue expenses.
